_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: California Tiltle 19 CalARP;29CFR 1910.120(q) First Responder Training

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and Federal EPA Risk Management Program requirements apply to California facilities that have quantities of hazardous materials over threshold values that were gauged to have a potential for a off-site impact. These facilities may be required to develop and submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP). The RMP must include the following key elements.

(1)Hazard Assessment
(2)Prevention Program
(3)Emergency Response
(4)External Events

Although in many ways an extension of the California Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) and Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements, there are many more Facilities encompassed by CalARP/RMP, and there are numerous differences that covered facilities must be sensitive to.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

In reviewing the potentially covered processes at California Dairies Inc. Tipton facility, the only Federally regulated RMP-covered process(<10k lbs.)is the Ammonia Refrigeration System. However in California having a lower threshold (<500 lbs.) this includes the Co-generation SCR Nox reduction process.

California Dairies uses the ammonia refrigeration system (Process 1) to chill, produce and hold product. The ammonia system utilized by California Dairies includes a liquid ammonia receiver. High-pressure liquid ammonia flows from the high-pressure receiver to the pump recirculator and then to the evaporators and silos where the pressure is reduced by allowing the ammonia to expand through expansion valves. The resulting low-pressure liquid ammonia is evaporated to provide refrigeration. Ammonia vapor exiting the evaporators is returned to the engine room. The resultant dry vapor is drawn to the compressors where it is compressed. The compressed vapor is then condensed to a liquid by rejecting heat to air and water in the evaporative condensers and draining that warm liquid by gravity to the  to the high-pressure receiver. 

In addition Califo

rnia Dairies uses ammonia for Nox reduction in the co-generation SCR ceramic grid. Ammonia vapor flows to dilution fans and is injected into the grid.                                                                  
                                                                                                                               This CalARP/RMP Submittal is offered to address the following regulatory requirement:

California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4, Sections 2735-2785, "California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP)"

Appendix A contains a copy of the Federal RMP Data Sheet Electronic Submittal, which was submitted for convienance to the AA:

This CalARP/RMP Submittal is designed to address the above regulatory requirements. The first section (CalARP & Supplemental US EPA RMP Information) links the US EPA RMP Submittal (copy provided in Appendix A) with CalARP-specific information.

The following paragraphs are reproduced from California Dairies Tipton facility US EPA RMP Submittal Executive Summary for the convenience of the reader.

California Dairies - Tipton is located at 11894 Avenue 120, Tipton, CA. The surrounding rural area consists of some residential development. The facility produces and stores dairy products. The ammonia refrigeration system is defined as a closed loop "Direct" type system.

The California Dairies Tipton facility has developed a risk management program to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4, EPA Title 40 CFR Part 68 and OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119) and to enhance an already existing safety and emergency action programs. California Dairies is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. California Dairies staff is highly trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and pr

ovide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia as a refrigerant.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

California Dairies has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System and Cogen systems. Their policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

As stipulated in EPA guidelines, 40 CFR Part 68.25, the worst-case and alternate case release scenarios were calculated for the covered process at the California Dairies facility and the written results of the off-site consequence scenarios are on file at the facility.

Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case event non-credible. In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., in the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entertainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:
-There are process valves to pe

rmit isolation of any leaks in place.
-Floor drains in the Engine Room would provide containment for liquid release and therefore minimize the potential for offsite impact.
-Plant personnel, as necessary, use Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
-The history of the Facility (i.e., no CalARP-applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Ammonia Refrigeration System.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this CalARP, key Prevention Program elements were implemented by California Dairies to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for refrigeration. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. 

Key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no CalARP/RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at the California Dairies facility in the past five years.

EMERGANCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

California Dairies has submitted this plan via CERS, which is available to numerous responding agencies.  This plan includes:

-Emergency Alarm Procedures
-Evacuation Procedures
-Safety and Health Considerations
-Notification Procedures

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several studies have been conducted to examine various measures to improve safety at the California Dairies Facility. These studies include a Hazard Analysis (HA), and Hazard Assessment. Both of these studies are permanent records within the facility Prevention Program. Items considered are the installation of an eye wash and shower on the lower roof at EC-1 and EC-2. The transfer of red-lined P&ID's to auto cad.
